required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Exploring the Role of Almonds in Enhancing Immune Strength
clinical_study.official_title: Exploring the Role of Almonds in Enhancing Immune Strength

brief_summary.textblock: The COVID-19 pandemic highlights the importance of good nutritional status for immune strength and for reducing comorbidities that increase morbidity and mortality of infections. The major aim of this study is test if almond consumption can improve immune function.

detailed_description.textblock: Investigators will conduct an 8-week parallel-arm trial of 48 overweight/non-obese (BMI=24-30) adult (aged 40-65 years) men (n=24) and women (n=24) who will be randomly assigned to consume daily isoenergetic portions of almonds or a common snack (pretzels).

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: forty-eight overweight/non-obese (BMI=24-30) adult (ages 40-65 years) men (n=24) and women (n=24) will be recruited to participate. A randomized, parallel-arm design will be utilized.

primary_outcome.description: The ability of peripheral blood mononuclear cells to bind and kill leukemia cells will be measured at baseline and at week-8 of the diet intervention using flowcytometry by assessing the concentration of natural killer cells.

secondary_outcome.description: Peripheral blood will be analyzed at baseline and week-8 of diet intervention for cytokines including IL1, IL-6 and TNF alpha concentrations.

arm_group.description: Consume 2 ounces almond daily for 8 weeks
Consume comparative amount of pretzel for 8 weeks

intervention.description: Consume 2 ounces of almond daily for 8 weeks
Consume comparative amount of pretzel daily for 8 weeks

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Healthy male and female subjects aged 40-65 y
- Body mass index (BMI) 24-30 kg/m.2
Exclusion Criteria:
- Not willing to stop taking multivitamins, and supplements (with the exception of vitamin D and calcium), for 30 days prior to or during study participation, if currently taking these.
- Almond allergies
- Alcohol consumption >2 drinks per day.
- Smoking or using nicotine containing products in the last 6 months.
